Description: The grounds stated in the appeal to the local tribunal, which are repeated

Transcription: That the above named, John James, aged 35 years, is an experienced Shepherd, and until the year 1913 held an appointment as a patrolling shepherd in Cardiganshire for two years. He is in the bona fide employment of the Appellant, the owner of Nantymoch Sheepwalk, Cardiganshire, comprising 1000 acres, and has charge of a stock of appellants sheep. The stock numbers about 1000 sheep including lambs. Appellant until last year let the sheepwalk to a tenant who left in September 1915. The latter had a stock of 1500 sheep on Nantymoch, and in a short time Appellants Stock will equal that in number. The said John James resides at Nantymoch Farm with his parents who are between 65 and 70 years of age. The father, William James, farms Nantymoch a farm comprising about 35 acres, and keeps 3 Horses, 12 Cows, (7 Milk Cows), and about 100 sheep, and is occupied most of his time in working and cultivating the farm, but occasionally assists his son the said John James. William James the father is wholly unable to undertake the duties of shepherd on so large a sheepwalk, and the employment of the said John James in indispensable. That the said John James is engaged in a certified occupation. Wm Thomas

Description: Reasons in support of the application of David Timothy Morris (158)

Transcription: REASONS IN SUPPORT OF THE APPLICATION I am a Master Boot and Shoe Maker and Repairer. There is only one other boot business in the whole parish. population is over 1,000 with an Elementary School within half a mile of my workshop and I have an extensive business in repairing boots for children attending the schools. I have customers in Llangwyryfon Llanddeiniol Blaenpenal and Llanon. There is a serious scarcity of Shoemakers and Repairers in my district. There are 9 miles from my workshop to Aberystwyth and only one Shoe Repairer and he is 5 miles away. Nine miles to Talsarn and no Shoemaker. 8 miles to Bronant and no Shoemaker. I have to work very long hours and I have now enough work for two workmen but I cannot get any assistance owing to the scarcity of men. I have a widowed Mother keeping my house and she is mainly dependent upon my earnings. Serious hardship would ensue if I gave up my business. I have invested all my money in the business and my money is out in the country with my customers. I appeal for conditional exemption owing to my exceptional financial and business obligations and also my domestic position. My business had been established for over 65 years. It was kept by Evan Lewis for 37 years, by my father for 21 years, and by myself for seven years. I have since the last hearing been examined by the Medical Board and been certified in Class C1. I apply for a re-hearing of my appeal.

Description: Letter of support for Thomas Morgan by D H Lloyd C. M. Minister, Cwmystwyth

Transcription: Re Mr Thomas Morgan, Tyrhyd, Cwmyswyth I have known Mr Thomas Morgan, Tyrhyd, Cwmystwyth, for the last fourteen years, and I have no hesitation in saying that he is totally unfit for any kind of military service. From 1904 to 1911 he was confined to his home by Asthma. Not only was he unable to do any work during that period so as to earn a livelihood, but suffered considerable pain. He spent several weeks and frequently longer periods without being able to lie down in bed. During the latter part of 1911 he was accidentally advised to try Doctor Tucker's "Asthma Specific". He secured the medicine immediately together with Doctor Tucker's "Atomizer", without which he could not inhale the medicine. After using it for about six months, he was able to go out of doors and commence work, and has been able to earn a livelihood ever since. For the last four years, during which he has had sufficient relief from Asthma to follow his employment as Roadman, he has been obliged to use the above mentioned Specific daily. A few days neglect would bring on an acute attack. During last August, he failed to secure a supply of the Specific, owing to Government restrictions re Cocaine, and was consequently confined to his house for three months, and was again unable to lie down in bed. At last he was premitted to have the supply again, and has followed his employment since. Mr Morgan, not only has to use this medicine at home, but is obliged to take the device with him to work to afford him relief. He is a martyr to acute asthma D.H. Lloyd C.M. Minister Cwmystwyth

Description: Handwritten letter [page 1 of 3] in support of the appeal of Alfred Edginton. Number '670' handwritten in top-right corner. Signed by 'T.J. [Thomas James] Waddingham' at bottom-right.

Transcription: This appeal is made on the ground that I am understaffed for carrying out work that is necessary in the National Interest to be done on my Hafod Estate of 16000 acres. I have a farm in hand of 370 acres of which 210 are mountain - 64 3/4 under the plough - 58 1/2 hay. 37 pasture. This year the arable land is cropped thus:- 17 acres wheat, 32 1/2ac oats, 4ac linseed, 3ac potatoes, 8 1/4ac roots. My stock is 7 agricultural horses requiring 3 men to follow them, 2 young horses, 18 cows, 22 young cattle, 570 sheep and lambs, 6 pigs. The cattle are for the most part pedigree shorthorns reared with the object of providing pure bred bulls for sale in the district to improve the quality of the local cattle. The rearing of young bulls require more labour that that of rearing bullocks as after a certain age one cannot allow the former out at grass. Besides the stock bull bought at Penrith at a cost of £242 I have 4 bulls calved in 1917 - all requiring more attention than can be given by an unexperienced person. Further I do not consider it right to put a woman in charge of such animals as they are never to be trusted. My cowman has to feed and to exercise these bulls, milk the cows, feed the calves and pigs, go around the mountain each day to see the sheep so that especially in maggoty weather he has as much as he can do. In addition to this cowman I have on the farm only 4 men and one girl - One of these four has for some time been in a very delicate state of health which caused him in January 1916 to give up the horses having worked them for 13 years. He has not been able to do a full days work for some time past. The farm is an awkward one to work having 3 sets of buildings in the form of a triangle, each rather over a mile from the next to it. It is a very high lying farm some of the arable land being over 900ft above sea level - very hilly and difficult to work. The rain fall is heavy - averaging for the past four years 61 1/2 inches per annum against 45 3/4 at Lampter, 43 1/2 at Aberystwyth, so as a necessary consequence we do not get as many farmable days [cont. on page 2]

Transcription: [cont. from page 1] for haymaking and harvest as do those farming in the low lands. Therefore more work must be done on the few fine days that we get and this can only by done by an increased supply of labour. For these reasons I think I am entitled to an increased ratio of labour to the area of arable land and amount of stock that is given to those in more favourable districts. Besides the farm work my carters and horses have to do all the carting necessary for the wood's sawmill and repairs to small holdings and cottages - there are on the Estate 40 holdings for the carting of materials for the repair of which I am liable as the occupiers do not keep a horse or pony. Consequently on the farm I do not get days when I can employ the carters away from their horses as happens on farms where there is no Estate work to be done. Besides the 5 men mentioned I have only available for all Estate or Forestry work 1 mason and two woodmen. In December and January last I did a considerable amount of sawing for the Cwmystwyth Mine Ltd, this among other sizes entailing the supplying of 4 baulks each 42'x12"x12". The timber in the round necessary to produce these dimensions weighing 2.5 tons each so that I had to employ four some times 5men on the work. Directly this order was completed I got to work on one for the Lisburne Development Syndicate - viz to supply the contractors timber - sawn square - necessary for the Launders for the new mine at Gwaith Coch - necessitating 14,000 sup ft [super foot] sawing - a great deal of the work being done by the man for whose service I am now appealing. I am now engaged on sawing a further lot of timber for the same company, the manager of which has asked me to try to supply him with the sawn timber for the whole of the new mill and power house below Grogwinion as well as for another launder. This I have promised to do if I have the necessary labour available on the understanding that I shall not be bound to keep the men sawing every day if I find I can take the men for a big part for haymaking or harvesting. Transcription: [cont. from page 2] All this work I am given to understand is urgently wanted by the Government who have written that the timber must if possible be obtained locally to economise in transport. [super foot] During the past 5 months I have had to fell about 4000 cub [cubic] ft [of] larch for local works - mostly in lots of 50-100 cu [cubic] ft for farmers for fencing posts - for farmers come to me from as far north as Borth - south as Berth and Lledrod, Aberystwyth in the west and Potallog [Bodtalog] in Radnorshire in the east. Annually in addition to the timber I sell about 160-200 load of firewood to local persons thus saving the transport of coal and in addition some 250 doz rails to farmers for fencing. I have recently had to pension off my old joiner who has worked on the Estate for almost 50 years so that practically all joiner work has to be done roughly by one of the sawyers. On all the farms on the Estate practically all the fences are composed of post-and-wire - for the supplying of the former I am liable and in this mountainous district a very large number have to be renewed each year. In the running of a farm with 64 3/4 acres under the plough - for the sawing urgently needed for Government work for a minimum of estate repairs for work in the woods I do not consider a staff of 8 men and 1 woman excessive. Should you not be able to reverse the decision of the Local Tribunal in this case - though I should do my best to carry on, some work of urgent national importance must be left undone. In July 1914 with less than 1/3 of what is now under the plough and no call whatever for converted timber I employed on less but similar work 16 men and 1 woman - just double of what I have today.

Transcription: The said David Rees Williams has been in trade as Builder and Contractor for the last 25 years, and has a large business connection. He is foreman and in full charge of the work and having regard to the reduction of staff and work to be done the services of this Richard Williams are indispensable.
